author: sky.cactus
content: It is a slippery slope toward on-chain governance, as someone described above.  In this case, it is a small innocuous change but it requires setting up the *infrastructure* to have on-chain governance.  For example, you have to decide who is on the multisig which is a huge step in the direction of on-chain governance systems.  Once that infrastructure is setup, it is easy/tempting to use it for more coordination problems in the future, and over time you run into a problem with an ever-expanding scope of what on-chain governance does.

author: sky.cactus
content: At the moment, we have a pretty bright line with regards to this problem, which is that client teams write software, users choose what software to run.  Introducing on-chain governance over *any* decision turns that bright line into a very fuzzy line, and fuzzy lines are easy to cross.  See <https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/Kbm6QnJv9dgWsPHQP/schelling-fences-on-slippery-slopes> for a more in-depth description of schelling fences (bright lines).
